text: Edmund Montague Morris, known as Edmund Morris (1871-1913), was a Canadian painter who painted portraits of First Nations people and collected their artifacts (many today in the collection of the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto as are the portraits). He was the co-founder of the Canadian Art Club. ==Biography== Morris was born on December 18, 1871 in Perth, Ontario. He attended Toronto Collegiate Institute, and later studied art under William Cruikshank. In the United States, he studied at the Art Students League of New York. In Europe he attended the Académie Julian and the École des Beaux-Arts in Paris. Morris settled in Toronto in 1896. His contemporaries included William Brymner, Maurice Cullen and Edmond Dyonnet. In 1905 Morris held a one- person show in Ottawa featuring portraits of native chiefs that he painted from photographs. In 1906 he accompanied a government expedition to James Bay district where he created more portraits. He continued making annual trips through 1910, painting Indigenous leaders. In 1907 he co-founded the Canadian Art Club. Morris was also a member of the The Arts and Letters Club of Toronto, the Ontario Society of Artists, the Toronto Art Students League, and the Royal Canadian Academy of Arts. He died on August 21, 1913 in Portneuf, Quebec. ==Gallery== Edmund Montague Morris- Opazatonka.jpg|Opazatonka Edmund Montague Morris-landscape.jpg|landscape Edmund Montague Morris-native chief Poundmaker, 1910.jpg|native chief Poundmaker, 1910 ==References== === Bibliography === *The Diaries of Edmund Montague Morris: Western Journeys 1907-1910 * ==External link== * Category:1871 births Category:1913 deaths Category:19th-century Canadian artists Category:20th-century Canadian artists
